In this session we will be discussing from two verses, the 47th and the 48th verses of the 8th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
The 47th verse
आह राजा धर्म सुतः चिन्तयन् सुरुदाम् वधं प्राकृतेन आत्मना विप्रा स्नेह मोह वशंगतः
The meaning of this verse is
King Yudhishthira, son of Dharma, overwhelmed by the death of his friends, was aggrieved just like a common materialistic man.
O sages!
Thus deluded by affection, he began to...
speak.
Suta Goswami is describing how Yudhishthira was aggrieved and what did he say, how did he express himself.
So he was overwhelmed just like a common man.
Now Srila Prabhupada explains something very significant in the purport.
Srila Prabhupada says,
King Yudhishthira, though he was not expected to become aggrieved like a common man,
became deluded by worldly affection by the will of the Supreme Lord Krishna.
Just as Arjuna was apparently deluded on the battlefield of Kurukshetra before the war began,
again by the arrangement of Krishna only.
Both Yudhishthira and Arjuna are pure devotees.
All the five Pandavas are pure devotees.
So there is no question of them becoming deluded by Maya.
So it is Krishna's arrangement for Arjuna to become deluded,
so that Krishna could speak Bhagavad Gita for our benefit.
Similarly, Krishna wanted Bhishma to instruct Yudhishthira.
And through Yudhishthira, Krishna wanted Bhishma to instruct the whole world about the intricacies of Dharma.
Hm?
And for that purpose, he was able to tell the whole world about the intricacies of Dharma.
And for that purpose, he was able to tell the whole world about the intricacies of Dharma.
Krishna arranged that Yudhishthira should become overwhelmed by worldly affection for the loss of so many people in this battle.
Shila Prabhupada explains in this purport, a man who sees knows well that the living entity is neither the body nor the mind, but is transcendental to the material conception of life.
You have heard this many times in the Bhagavad Gita and all the scriptures it is explained, we are spirit soul, we are not the body, we are not the mind.
Both the gross body and the subtle body.
are coverings for the real person within the body, that is the spirit soul.
The common man thinks of violence and non-violence in terms of the body, but that is a kind of delusion.
Just considering the body alone is a big mistake.
Everyone is duty bound according to one's occupation.
Occupational duties, swadharma or varnashrama dharma.
A kshatriya is bound to fight for the right cause regardless of the opposite party.
In this case, Yudhishthira was fighting against his own cousins, the Kauravas.
But for the right cause, a kshatriya should not refuse to fight.
That is what Krishna explains in the Bhagavad Gita to Arjuna also.
In discharge of duty, one should not be disturbed by annihilation of the material body, which is only an external dress of the living soul.
In the Bhagavad Gita in the second chapter, Krishna explains,
Just like this cloth we are wearing is simply an external covering for the real person within the dress.
Similarly,
The body itself, the physical body is simply an external covering of the spirit soul.
And when it is worn out, then one discards that.
That is what is called death, discarding this body and accept a new body.
All this was perfectly known to Yudhishthira Maharaj.
But by the will of the Supreme Lord Krishna, he became just like a common man.
Because there was another great idea behind this delusion.
Krishna had another plan, why Yudhishthira should become deluded.
What is that great idea?
King Yudhishthira would be instructed by Bhishma.
As Arjuna was instructed by Lord Krishna himself.
This was the idea.
For Yudhishthira to become deluded.
Because of the massacre, mass massacre.
The 48th verse.
Aho me pashyata ajnanam.
Hridhirudham duratmanah.
Parakyasyaiva dehasyah.
Aho me akshauhinir hatah.
The meaning of this verse is, King Yudhishthira said,
O my Lord, I am the most sinful man.
Just see my heart, which is full of ignorance.
This body, which is ultimately meant for others, has killed many many phalanxes of men.
Phalanx means akshauhini in Sanskrit.
Then the purport should be appropriate to explain what is the count of a phalanx or akshauhini division.
A solid phalanx of 21,870 chariots.
21,870 elephants.
109,650 infantry.
And 65,600 cavalry is called an akshauhini.
Chariots here mean chariot fighters.
And elephants means on elephant back there are powerful warriors who fight from elephant back.
And infantry means those on foot, soldiers on foot.
And cavalry means those who are on horseback.
Fighters on horseback.
So, these four kinds of fighters are there in a battle in the Vedic times, in the Vedic culture.
So, akshauhini division is very very big.
21,000 and odd chariots.
21,000 and odd elephants.
109,000 infantry.
And 65,000 odd cavalry.
So many.
And like this how many divisions were there?
Totally on the battlefield of Kurukshetra.
11 on the Kaurava side.
11 akshauhini divisions on the Kaurava side.
And 7 akshauhini divisions on the Pandava side.
Totally 18 akshauhini divisions were fighting in this battle of Kurukshetra.
So, Prabhupada further explains.
Many akshauhinis were killed on the battlefield of Kurukshetra.
That's a fact.

takes for himself the responsibility for killing such a huge number of living beings
